title: Towards functional spin-echo BOLD line-scanning in humans at 7T - Magnetic Resonance Materials in Physics, Biology and Medicine

last_post.content:
Null-findings are important, but more difficult to prove and publish. Here is a null-finding #NewPaper / #NeuroNewPaper.

Line-scanning functional #MRI has both high spatial and high temporal resolutions, about 200 micrometers and 200 milliseconds. This is achieved by sacrificing spatial coverage, akin to a virtual BOLD electrode through the brain. Previously, we implemented a human line-scanning sequence using gradient-echo #BOLD #fMRI at 7T.

Spin-echo MRI sequences offer several advantages over gradient-echo MRI sequences, for example much improved spatial line-selection and microvascular specificity. However, despite many efforts, especially from the lead-author Luisa Raimondo, spin-echo line-scanning currently lacks adequate sensitivity for #neuroscience applications.

title: The geometry of cortical representations of touch in rodents - Nature Neuroscience

last_post.content:
#NeuroPaperThread #NeuroNewPaper

1) Our article “The geometry of cortical representations of touch in rodents” with @chrisXrodgers Randy Bruno and @StefanoFusi is finally out! In brief, we found that whisker contacts in mice S1 are represented in approximately orthogonal subspaces https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-022-01237-9 🧵​👇​

Because of reasons (see https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.3000356 ) we decided to try to disassemble the communities —i.e. isolate each member species from a community and then rebuild the community with fixed initial population sizes— between rounds of selection.

This allows us to change the species composition and explore the landscape of different communities. As an effect, we can find communities that degrade better than the initial ones, i.e. we can actually IMPROVE the max function.

Visual cortex is affected by sounds. Does this mean it is multisensory? Does it represent sounds?

Today in Nature #Neuroscience (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41593-022-01227-x) Célian Bimbard and team find otherwise.

Sound-evoked activity in visual cortex was similar across neurons. Even neurons in hippocampus. It persisted after we cut fibers from auditory cortex!

This activity was predicted by… subtle body movements evoked by the sounds. It reflects brainwide state and behavior signals.

@aparrish We see related problems in clinical #neurology, where our diagnostic criteria for aphasia assume English structure. E.g., one diagnostic criterion for semantic dementia is "surface dysgraphia"--improper regularization, like writing "yacht" as "yot." But this criterion relies on English's orthographic opacity, and wouldn't appear in languages like Spanish, Korean or Russian with more regular orthography.

Here's a fascinating paper by my colleague Boon Lead Tee on dysgraphia in Chinese-speakers with primary progressive aphasia: https://doi.org/10.1212/wnl.0000000000200350. Because Chinese writing is so different from English, these disorders manifest in really interestingly different ways--some analogous to presentations in English, others entirely distinct. Anyway, a challenge for cross-cultural diagnosis and management...

title: Free energy and specific heat near a quantum critical point of a metal

last_post.content: Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01873 by Zhang et. al. Authors study the free energy and specific heat for fermions interacting with gapless bosons at a quantum-critical point (QCP) in a metal. Three cases considered: Ising-nematic QCP, AFM QCP, & QCP for electrons interacting with Einstein phonons. Specific heat in the full fermion-boson model is independent of the cutoff and is positive all the way up to QCP. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2301_01873
